channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Letter From Europe: Britain Embraces Defeat, in Sports and Politics
item.description: As the England squad flew home from the World Cup, Prime Minister David Cameron braced for defeat at the European Commission.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: The soccer player Wayne Rooney at a press conference Saturday after England was eliminated from contention in the World Cup.

item.title: North Korea Fires 3 Short-Range Projectiles
item.description: Action comes a day after Pyongyang warned of retaliation against an American comedy film in which two Americans are recruited to kill Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Britain Chronicles Abuse by Jimmy Savile at Medical Facilities
item.description: A report by the Department of Health is likely to rekindle public revulsion about the former entertainer once seen as a national treasure.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Graduates’ Red Guard Photos Cast Doubt on What They Learned
item.description: Photos of graduating students playing out a scene from the Cultural Revolution have gone viral on Chinese websites and brought comments about the suppression of public discussion of history.
item.dc:creator: By KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: University students in Harbin dressed as Red Guards staged a Cultural Revolution scene for their graduation.

item.title: Carney Details New Weapons to Cool British Housing Market
item.description: The moves announced by Mark J. Carney, governor of the Bank of England, would restrict large mortgage loans as a way to curb market distortions.
item.dc:creator: By JENNY ANDERSON

item.title: Jordanian Court Acquits Islamic Cleric in Terrorism Case
item.description: Abu Qatada was deported by Britain last year after a long legal fight over whether he would receive a fair trial in his home country.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Iraqi Parliament to Meet to Form New Government
item.description: Lawmakers will assemble on Monday to debate the formation of a new coalition as they come under pressure to include more Sunni and Kurdish representatives.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Missing Malaysian Jet’s Crew Was Likely Unresponsive, Officials Say
item.description: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 appears to have been on autopilot as it flew south, and the crew may have been incapacitated, officials said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Opium Production on the Rise Worldwide, U.N. Reports
item.description: The annual study said more land than ever was devoted to growing poppies, and noted a rise in the use of methamphetamines and marijuana in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Antarctica via France, and Other Tales of Official Expense-Padding
item.description: An Antarctica tour that somehow included visits to Chile and France was among the infractions described in reports on 37 Chinese government departments and agencies released this week by the National Audit Office.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Cyclist on Course to Be Country’s First Tour de France Rider
item.description: Team Giant-Shimano has announced that Ji Cheng made its list of nine riders expected to participate in the 21-stage, 2,272-mile race.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Ji Cheng leading the pack during the fifth stage of the Vuelta a España race in northern Spain on Aug. 22, 2012.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: William C. Kirby on ‘Can China Lead?’
item.description: In the book “Can China Lead?”, three business school professors looked at the motors for and the constraints against greatness that China is experiencing. One of the authors, William C. Kirby, explains what they found.
item.category: Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: An honor guard of the People's Liberation Army marching after an official ceremony at the Great Hall of the People, along the west side of Tiananmen Square in Beijing.

item.title: Issue of Pay for 2 Sets of Workers Tugs at Palestinian Pact
item.description: The Palestinian prime minister says he does not have enough money to pay both workers hired by Hamas and those employed by the Palestinian Authority.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abu Raid al-Samouni, 46, a driver and office cleaner in Gaza, has received only part of his $350 monthly salary since October.

item.title: Violence and Uncertainty Mar Libyan Election for a New Parliament
item.description: Voters cited growing disillusionment with Libya’s post-revolt leaders in explaining why so many chose not to cast ballots Wednesday for members of a new Parliament.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and SULIMAN ALI ZWAY
item.media:description: Women voted Wednesday at a polling station inside a Tripoli school as Libyans elected members of a new Parliament.

item.title: World Briefing: South Korea: A Familiar Premier
item.description: President Park Geun-hye reversed her decision to replace her current prime minister, after two successive appointees stepped aside amid controversies over their qualifications.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Taiwan Protest Leaders Blocked From Visiting Hong Kong
item.description: Lin Fei-fan, Chen Wei-ting and Huang Kuo-chang had planned to attend a forum next Monday by the New School for Democracy. They had also planned to attend a protest march on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Lin Fei-fan, center, one of the protest leaders denied entry to Hong Kong, at a demonstration outside the Taiwan hotel where China's top cross-strait official, Zhang Zhijun, was meeting with his local counterpart, Wang Yu-chi.

item.title: Use of Drones for Killings Risks a War Without End, Panel Concludes in Report
item.description: The group of military, intelligence and legal experts warned of a “slippery slope” to perpetual war and the dangers of setting bad precedents for foes.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Deadly Blast Hits Capital
item.description: An explosion killed 21 people in a crowded shopping district in Nigeria’s capital, Abuja, during rush hour on Wednesday, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Corsica: Militants Vow to Disarm
item.description: The National Liberation Front of Corsica, a militant group that has staged attacks since the 1970s in its quest for Corsica’s separation from France, announced Wednesday in a surprise move that it would lay down arms.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing: Bahrain: An Opposition Acquittal
item.description: Khalil al-Marzooq had been accused of instigating violence and having links to a protest faction that the authorities blame for bombings.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Bolivia: Politicians Reverse Time
item.description: In a move tied to the hemisphere’s winter solstice, the government flipped the clock atop the Congress building this week so that, while it is still accurate, the numbers are reversed, and the hands now turn to the left.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Sri Lanka: Advisers Set for Inquiry
item.description: The United Nations named three international experts on Wednesday to be advisers on an inquiry into human rights abuses in the final months of Sri Lanka’s war against ethnic Tamil insurgents in 2009.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Man Kills Himself at Beirut Hotel as Security Closes In
item.description: Lebanon’s interior minister called a “pre-emptive strike” against a terrorist cell preparing to strike elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Pakistani Militants
item.description: The United States froze the assets of two senior members of Lashkar-e-Taiba and designated the Pakistani group’s charity wing as a front organization.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Shiite Violence Traps Baghdad’s Sunnis, Haunted by a Grim Past
item.description: Sunnis fear that walls built by the Americans to protect them could also entrap them, making them easy prey for emboldened Shiite militias who executed Sunnis in large numbers not many years ago.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives mourned Thaha Ahmed Shabab, 62, a Sunni who was fatally shot on the road in front of his home on Tuesday night.
